channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: Wealth of opportunities for NZ entrepreneurs after lockdown
item.description: Despite dour economic predictions, the Covid-19 recovery offers opportunities for entrepreneurial success beyond any seen for decades, Dr Tadhg Ryan-Charleton writes.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 21 April
item.description: A New Zealander was confirmed dead in Peru, more mercy flights for Kiwis abroad were planned, and an audit of PPE was announced.

item.title: Covid-19: What happens when a foodbank runs out of food
item.description: Checkpoint - A Masterton foodbank's supplies ran dry after seeing a three-fold increase in demand late last week.

item.title: Air NZ silent about Covid-19 cases as staff fears grow over quarantine exemption
item.description: Checkpoint - Air New Zealand is keeping secret the number of its staff infected with Covid-19 amid allegations it is not doing enough to keep its workers safe.

item.title: Covid-19 response: More repatriation flights on the way
item.description: The government is planning more repatriation flights for New Zealanders stuck overseas.

item.title: Covid-19: GPs say promised government funding not received
item.description: General practitioners say they have been denied millions of dollars of promised Covid-19 funding.

item.title: Covid-19 lockdown: Migrant workers in Queenstown without jobs, food
item.description: Some migrant workers in Queenstown have been stranded without pay for weeks, the Salvation Army says.

item.title: Covid-19 alert level 3 questions answered: The nitty gritty
item.description: Yesterday we covered off the beginner's guide to level 3, including advice for the lovelorn, today we dive into some more detailed questions from you, our beloved audience.

item.title: Man shot by police in South Auckland named
item.description: The machete-wielding man who was shot dead by police in South Auckland yesterday has been named.

item.title: Covid-19: Live updates from New Zealand and around the world on 21 April
item.description: Read back over the day's events for everything related to Covid-19 in New Zealand today.

item.title: New Zealand migrant worker market may face tough new policies - academic
item.description: Higher unemployment and election year populism may be the recipe for a sharp tightening of immigration policy, according to a leading academic.

item.title: Wellington hospitality sector looks to rev back into gear
item.description: Wellington is planning new events to help the city's economy recover after the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Covid-19 lockdown: Traffic data shows New Zealanders staying put
item.description: Record low traffic and public transport data from the third week of lockdown shows New Zealanders are continuing to heed the message to stay home.

item.title: Covid-19: Government reassures teachers, parents over school reopening
item.description: School playgrounds will be off limits and children will be kept in bubbles of no more than 10 when schools partially reopen next week.

item.title: Covid-19: Scientists need 'to do better' to find ways to trace contacts
item.description: Scientists need to find fresh ideas for how to track the contacts of people who may have had Covid-19, as case numbers plummet, a scientist says.

item.title: Dr Ashley Bloomfield takes public questions in live Q+A
item.description: Dr Ashley Bloomfield and Education Secretary Iona Holsted have held a live Q+A on Facebook to talk about health and education.

item.title: Decision on Mataura hazardous waste due next week
item.description: Authorities will decide next week whether the removal of 10,000 tonnes of hazardous waste from Mataura's disused paper mill can continue under level 3 restrictions.

item.title: Sex assault-acquitted police officer's actions fell short of standards - IPCA
item.description: While there is insufficient evidence to prove either of two sexual assaults a senior Northland police officer is accused of, some of his actions fell short of police standards, the IPCA says.
